item.title: If-Then-Else Statements? Help meh out?
item.dc:creator: @relmitos relmitos
item.description:
@relmitos wrote:

The code in ‘else’ will execute if the condition in ‘if’ is not met.

item.title: If-Then-Else Statements? Help meh out?
item.dc:creator: @vManlyMan vManlyMan
item.description:
@vManlyMan wrote:

I don’t understand what you mean when you say, “Then is closer to the first bracket in the if statement”.

Would I just not have another line of

if(playerRights !=2) {

It would just be

if(playerRights =2) {
additem(999, 999);
} else {
sM(“no”);
}

Read full topic

item.title: If-Then-Else Statements? Help meh out?
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

[quote=“vManlyMan, post:3, topic:394882”]What would an example be?

Like

if(playerRights = 2) { then(addItem(995, 1000); } else { if(playerRights > 2); sM("you must be an admin"); }Would that work?[/quote]

Close but no.

“Then” actually is closer to the first { in the if statement.

Think of it as:

if (this is true) then
doSomething
else
doSomethingElse

Read full topic

its basically saying if this requirment is met this “this” will happen but if its not met then it wont happen errm im not good at explaining a requirment could be a skill level or certain playerright or memberstatus but pretty much its just saying what will happen if you have what is stated and what it does if you dont have the requirment stated to do the action

item.title: If-Then-Else Statements? Help meh out?
item.dc:creator: @vManlyMan vManlyMan
item.description:
@vManlyMan wrote:

I found this tutorial called, Basic Coding, inside of Mendomorphin’s RSPS tools file. I was reading through the tutorial and got to the Statements section. Could somebody better explain if-then-else statements please and tell me what I could use them for? (In commands and teleports and such). Thanks for anyone who at least tries.

[code]if-then-else statements are about the same. They are basically two if-then statements combined.

There are two ways to use them.

Quote:
if(req = true){
then();

} else {

ifReqWasntMet();
}

Or you can do this ===================================

if(req = true){
then();

} else if(req = false) {

ifReqWasntMet();
}

If you read the beginning, you should understand this.
Understand? If not, then google biconditionals.

Anyway, this would be applied in nearly EVERYTHING that has requirements unless you use a switch.

-Original author believed to be “TeleNubby” of MoparScape ???[/code]

Read full topic
